Message To User
Hello user, Welcome to Cyber Lock! To begin, privacy and security is very important to me, with the increasing attacks on privacy and security, I decided to create an application for mobile device to store data as of now locally but most importantly securely. This is my personal, private ongoing encryption application project. This is my take on trying to make mobile application software and security more noticeably intertwined. I spend many hours researching, designing and developing. I very much hope to continue my project and bring constant updates to upgrade and improve Cyber Lock. I plan on implementing many other features and options to give you, the user, more control over how you keep your data safe. Furthermore, I am constantly experimenting with visuals to provide cleaner looks and overall greater practicality. I believe in simplicity, power, reliability, but greatest of all, an uncompromising balance of security and privacy!
Sincerely, GG. Contribute ( Donate, Rate/Review, Share )
Cyber Lock\'s Technology
Cyber Lock is a mobile application designed to secure and privatize your personal information. Cyber Lock is equipped to utilize four different symmetric Encryption Algorithms; AES, Blowfish, RC4 and Triple DES. Pins are protected using a salted SHA-256 algorithm, a powerful one-way hash function that cannot be decrypted.
AES
Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is a newer and stronger encryption standard, which uses the Rijndael algorithm. This algorithm was developed by Joan Daemen and Vincent Rijmen of Belgium. AES has a block size of 128 and is able to use 128, 192, and 256-bit keys for powerful encryption.
Blowfish Blowfish is a symmetric block cipher, designed by Bruce Schneier. Blowfish has a 64-bit block size and a variable key length from 32 up to 448 bits.
SHA-256
SHA-256 (Secure Hash Algorithm), a cryptographic function which takes an input and spits out an alphanumeric string. SHA-256 generates an almost-unique, fixed 256-bit hash. A hash is a one way function “encryptor” which cannot be decrypted. SHA-256 is currently one of the strongest functions available.
